Award.AwardTitle: Workshop Proposal: Machine Learning and Discovery Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The emergence of big data has been transformational in many areas in science and engineering - biology, health sciences, material science, physics, and so on. At the heart of this transformation is statistical machine learning, a subfield of computer science that aims at studying and developing algorithms that can analyze large volumes of data. The goal of this international workshop is to bring together researchers, both from USA and Armenia, who work on machine learning (ML) and other scientific disciplines that are poised to benefit from the recent advances in ML.

The workshop will include participation from leading experts in a number of disciplines. In machine learning, the workshop will cover topics such as deep learning, tensor methods, unsupervised learning with high dimensional data, and so on. In computational social sciences, the topics will include social network analysis, behavioral modeling, modeling of socio-technical systems. And in computational biology, the topics will cover gene expression analysis, computational neuroscience, predictive diagnostics. The workshop will serve as a bridge to get these communities talking to one another and explore collaborative research. The workshop will provide a forum for the participating researchers to formulate a research agenda that will help to utilize recent advances in ML in data-intensive disciplines. Second, the workshop will support participation of senior graduate students and early career scientists. Finally, the workshop will promote scientific cooperation between the American and Armenian researchers.

This award is cofunded by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As intended, the workshop provided a unique opportunity for the US and Armenian researchers to network and identify possible points of collaboration with their counterparts. All three objectives of the workshop were achieved:

 

  • Fostering cross-disciplinary collaborations between ML and data-intensive disciplines: The workshop sessions, and especially the panels, were organized to emphasize cross-disciplinary interactions and exchange between the participants. For instance, in the Computational Social Sciences sessions, the topics touched upon ML and data science, graph analytics, social & communication sciences, and statistical physics. In computational biology sessions, participants included computational biologists as well as ML experts.
  • Initiating collaborative projects between US and Armenian researchers: the workshop participants engaged in few collaborative projects:  i) the researchers from University of Southern California (USC) and the Institute of Molecular Biology (IMB) in Yerevan have discussed potential collaboration within the US-funded project; ii) USC and Harvard Medical School have started partnership on computational neuro science, possibly also involving partners from Armenia;
  • Exploring collaboration mechanisms between NSF and FAST: i) Naira Hovakimyan (co-PI) presented in CPS week in April, 2018, in the NSF workshop “A Visioning Workshop for International Networks to Advance CPS Research, Development, and Education Worldwide”, where she reported on collaboration opportunities between FAST and NSF; ii) Some of the workshop participants, specifically from USC, and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC), discussed preliminary arrangements with the TUMO center  (https://tumo.org/en/) for cooperation.
  • The workshop participants also discussed a broad range of possibilities for future collaborations, based on the unique and complementary strength of research environment in Armenia. The workshop also contributed greatly in shaping up the field of AI/DS direction in Armenia in general, and in particular culminating in the Data Science undergraduate degree program being introduced at the American University of Armenia for the Fall 2018 semester. 

 

Dissemination: Overall, more than 500 people attended the workshop, most of whom students from the local universities studying in STEM programs. The workshop was extensively covered in local press as well as on social media platforms such as Twitter (#ML4Sciences). All the sessions of the workshop except the last one were also broadcasted live on Youtube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vPlkRWBzm1Q).
